projectDesc.p: "The saying of the cook of the famous duke of Milan" is published by The Global Medieval Sourcebook (GMS), a free, open access, and open source compendium of medieval texts in their original languages and in English translation. GMS comprises computer-readable transcriptions or editions alongside new translations of texts dating from the ninth to the sixteenth century and originating in Europe, North Africa, the Middle East, and Asia. The GMS platform includes critical introductions as well as sources for further reading.

editorialDecl.p: Transcriptions and translations are encoded in XML conforming to TEI (P5) guidelines. The original-language text is contained within <lem> tags and translations within <rdg> tags.

interpretation.p: Texts are translated into modern American English with maximum fidelity to the original text, except where it would impair comprehension or good style. Archaisms are preserved where they do not conflict with the aesthetic of the original text. Scribal errors and creative translation choices are marked and discussed in the critical notes.

app.lem: Dux Mediolani senior, Princeps in omnibus rebus elegantiae singularis, habebat cocum egregium quem usque ad Gallos ad perdiscenda obsonia miserat.
app.rdg: The older duke of Milan, a most refined ruler when all things were concerned, had a distinguished cook, whom he sent all the way to France to fully learn their dishes.

app.lem: Bello, quod ingens cum Florentinis Dux habuit, cum ei aliquando non satis prosper nuntius advenisset, admodum turbavit Ducis mentem.
app.rdg: Once during the war, which the great duke waged against Florence, the duke became very upset because he had received less than favourable news.

app.lem: Oblatis postmodum ad mensam epulis, sapores nescio quos cum Dux improbasset, epulas insuper, ut non rite conditas, esset aspernatus,
app.rdg: Later on at dinner a feast was presented, but the duke had rejected several sauces and had even spurned a dish for not being correctly spiced.

app.lem: accitum cocum veluti ignarum artis aspere increpavit.
app.rdg: The cook was summoned and severely rebuked for not knowing his art.

app.lem: Tum ille, ut erat liberior in eloquendo:
app.rdg: Since he was quite unrestrained in speaking out, the cook then said:

app.lem: 'Si Florentini,' inquit, 'tibi gustum atque appetitum auferunt, quae mea est culpa?
app.rdg: “If the Florentines have taken away your taste and appetite, why is that my fault?

app.lem: My food is well-tasting and made with the highest skill: but the Florentines have roasted you thoroughly and taken away your appetite.”
app.rdg: Cibi enim mei sapidi sunt, et summa arte compositi: sed te nimium concalefaciunt, et appetitum auferunt Florentini.'

app.lem: Risit ille, ut erat humanissimus, coci facetam in respondendo libertatem.
app.rdg: The duke, who was very humane, laughed at the cook’s elegant reply and the liberty he took.
